text:
Hello. Welcome to this session
of This is My Architecture.
My name is Guillaume, I am with

Jonathan from Thales.
Hello Jonathan.
Hello Guillaume.
Could you explain to us what Thales is,
and what your role is at Thales?

Yes, of course! Well, I'm part
of the Thales DIS division

which is related to identity
and digital security.

My role within this division
is to take care of security

which are... in relation to the Thales DIS,
solutions that are hosted on AWS.
All right, great.

Could you please explain to us
what this architecture is all about,
and what it does?

All right, on this architecture,
what we've tried to do

is to centralize all the security events
on a single point,
so that we can identify them in a better way

and then be able to process
them automatically if possible.
All right, I see several components.
Could you tell us more about these components
and the links between them?

Of course! Well, we have
the security hub component.

What we're going to try to do
is to provision
the Guard Duty first.

The Guard Duty allows us 
to analyze AWS logs,
to find suspicious activity.

So, all these events 
will be provisioned on Security Hub.

The second AWS service 
we use is AWS Inspector.

It will also push the events 
related to the SVEs
which are found on the devices,

because thanks to AWS Inspector,
we can do vulnerability scans.

Then, we have other services
that are not related to AWS.
First of all, we have the antivirus.

We make sure that all events 
related to the antivirus
are also provisioned on Security Hub.
And the last one is the HIDS,

which allows us to do 
OS log analysis on the EC2s,

in order to also detect activities
that could be unwanted or suspicious.

It also allows us to upload 
this information to the Security Hub
and have all the events in one place.

All right, so Security Hub allows you 
to aggregate, and centralize events

whether they come from AWS services
or from partner services
that you chose.

Exactly.
- Great.

Letâ€™s go further,
Security Hub is aggregating everything,
and what happens next?

Well, once we have all 
the events in one place,

we can see the activity
in our infrastructure more clearly.
It's still security-related.
We'll process events from Security Hub.

And events generated on Security Hub
will create a Cloud Watch Event.

This Cloud Watch Event
will then launch a Step Function.

At the Step Function level,
we're going to have Lambdas libraries,
which will perform small, specific actions.

So, thanks to these specific actions,
we will be able to build
automatic remediations
for each type of security incident.

Once we've been able to process
the incident automatically,

it will create a ticket in the ITSM
that will be closed,

or if we need to have a manual action,
the ticket will be left open.

So, the incident will be left open
for an analyst to review.
We also have integration with Slack.

We'll have a channel
with all the security events
that we think are important.

And the last one is that 
we've done the integration with Pager Duty

which allows you
to  directly call a security analyst,
in the event of a critical or high incident.

All right, so Cloudwatch serves as a bus,
Step Function as a workflow,

and then it tries to remediate,
and sends notifications

to an instant messaging,
creates a ticket and does an escalation.

Can Step Function achieve
the complete remediation?

Or is there another process 
in the background?

If we have prospectively developed 
all the necessary Lambdas

to do an automatic remediation
and a security event,
we can cover the event in the right way.

For some events, we sometimes
haven't done the development yet
and we will need an analyst

to do the manual investigation,
to understand the incident, and solve it.
All right, great.
What did you get out of that solution?

Today that solution is in production,
what did you get out of it?
It gave us a better visibility on all the events
because we have a main console

where we are able to see all
the events in one place,
which is easier than having different consoles

where we have to log in in order
to see what's going on,
so, we really have a global view,

and thanks to Security Hub,
where we have a unique format

no matter what type of event 
is at the source,
we are able to process it in an easier way.

Thus, we speed up our development
to perform automatic remediations.
All right, great.
Thank you very much for the presentation.

Thank you for watching 
This is My Architecture. See you soon.
